content.body: jwalden: per spec h2-h6 don't actually do the magic sizing, only h1 does
huh
haven't seen that change
in the spec
maybe it's part of the rendering section
change?
h2-h6 have never done magic sizing, it's always only been <h1>
bad assumptions on my part, I guess
requiring h2-h6 to do magic sizing would be orders of magnitude more complexity, since then we'd have to do the entire outline algorithm each time
hm, my mis-memory
Hixie: "not appliciable" in the status boxes probably shouldn't use the same icons as "excellent support"
fixed
now it's the same as none
anyone aware of bugs in browsers with <param>?
hmm what's the impl status of "Offsets into the media resource" (i.e. .duration, .currentTime, .loop)?
"incomplete" in firefox and safari?
haven't tested either recently
what about canvas transformations?
Philip`?
skips the canvas-related sections
currentTime works in Gecko, modulo bugs of course
duration also seems to work
Hixie: "The rendering section will define this in more detail." says the spec about size=""
jwalden: the outline algorithm is a known feature request for v.nu
so I figured :-)
jwalden: right now I'm focusing on the Gecko side of things, tyranny of email permitting
all good, not like I had a meaningful reason to need it :-)
zcorpan: i'll clean that up at some point
uh... why is there an annotation box at 5.9.4 The Location interface that seems to annotate something about <video>?
probably the IDs changed
it happens occasionally
is it fixable?
only by making IDs never get reused
which browsers support rel=prefetch?
firefox is the only one i know of
zcorpan: What about canvas transformations?
Philip`: which browsers support them (for the purpose of spec status annotation)?
Philip`: maybe you could go through the canvas section and annotate appropriately? :)
http://philip.html5.org/tests/canvas/suite/tests/results.html#2d.transformation.transform.identity says all supported transform, and all except WebKit supported setTransform
Hmm, it's possible but I don't think I really care enough to do that :-p
ooh. YouTube automatic caption translation is impressive
nessy: what capture software do you use to generate the green circles indicating clicks?
aargh. I already have a validator bug related to xmlns:foo
gestures angrily in the general direction of Namespaces
If you would just stop writing bugs, it wouldn't be a problem at all
Hixie: the first "ABC Company" example should be marked as "bad"
zcorpan: k, thx
are webkit's and firefox's impl of canvas text "incomplete" or "complete but buggy"?
ok i'm done annotating now. they were rough guesses but it's better than nothing, i hope
argh. the isindex bug persists
Hixie, one issue Ruby raised a few times was making <meta charset> conforming in XHTML if it matched the charset of the document
annevk: I categorize that under violations of the DOM Consistency principle being bad

we could allow <meta charset> in XHTML if it was set to either UTF-8, UTF-16, UTF-16LE or UTF-16BE; or if it matched the encoding specified by the XML declaration or higher level protocol, like the HTTP content-type header
presumes it also falls under the Metadata That Looks Like It'll Do Something But Actually It'll Be Totally Ignored Thus Wasting Authors' Time principle (like @profile)
@profile is different
Philip`: indeed. Which is why what Lachy says would only work for authors who validate often but would cause trouble for everyone else
hsivonen: It would also work for authors who don't validate at all but send everything as UTF-8 all the time and use <meta charset="utf-8"/>
which is probably quite a high proportion of the people who serve XHTML
@profile is an epic waste of time no matter what. However, if the WG doesn't spent its time on it, the aggregate waste over time will be much larger.
at least allowing <meta charset> in XHTML would actually be addressing a real use case
unlike @profile
forgets the usecase
jgraham, allowing polyglot documents to be served as either HTML or XHTML without modification and without relying on HTTP content type headers
Yes
rubys said that's what Venus does

jgraham: Software that produces bytes that someone else (who doesn't want to do any fancy reserialiation) might serve as HTML or XHTML, that will retain the correct charset even when it's e.g. saved to disk and separated from its HTTP charset
I suppose polyglot documents are a valid usecase
They're a use case which HTML5 already goes to some lengths to support, so it'd be inconsistent to not continue supporting them
hmm, in that case, maybe we would only need to allow it to be specified as UTF-8/UTF-16*, because if you're specifying the charset with the xml decl. then you're not making a polyglot document
... and doing anything else doesn't work too well when separated from the HTTP content-type headers
Lachy: Can't Content-Type still set the charset to anything (not just UTF), if there's no XML declaration?
Philip`, yeah, but see what I just wrote
Philip`: if you can set content-type you don't need <meta charset>
I suppose that makes sense
we may not even need to allow UTF-16, since that has the BOM anyway
zcorpan: though being able to vary the content-type without being able to also set charset is a very fringe case
hsivonen: Not really - just upload an .html vs .xhtml file, and that'll change the content-type
(or have an .html and .xhtml file on your local disk)
ok
notes that this is can already be done by using the UTF-8 BOM
hsivonen, sometimes, including the UTF-8 BOM isn't always easy and can create problems with server side tools
would never trust a text editor to not silently strip the BOM
e.g. if you begin a PHP file with the UTF-8 BOM, then it sends it out and prevents you from calling header() to set any other headers.
would trust TextWrangler
Lachy: so you'd need to produce the BOM by other means than literal inclusion in PHP
the only safe way to get a BOM output from such a system is to do: echo "\EF\BB\BF"
right
(if I got that syntax right)

I guess any server-side templating system which reads a template, parses it as XML, does some substitutions, then prints it out again, would be hard to make output a BOM if you're the person who's just editing the templates
<meta charset="utf-8"/> is easier to work with than a bom
but that requires authors to have to look up the byte sequence for the UTF-8 BOM, which is harder than just typing <meta charset="UTF-8"/>
true. I just observed that there is an unobvious and brittle way to address the case already.
The use case could also be addressed by outputting ASCII and using &#nnn;
Philip`: that might be safer to do anyway
since for rubys' purpose the content might well end up being mislabeled anyway
Inefficient for non-English-speakers, though
efficient enough for swedish, but yeah
PHP doesn't do BOM
it chokes on it (at least for version 4 it did, maybe it's fixed now)
with PHP, you are in control of headers, on the other hand
if you know how that works
zcorpan: Still probably three times worse than UTF-8 for any funny Swedish characters, though
well, yeah, pretty much everything depends on knowing what to do
I expect that most people that work with PHP have limited knowledge of headers
s/headers/HTTP/
Headers are things like <META>, aren't they?
Philip`: yes but for a normal document that's still not so much
Swedish characters are two bytes in UTF-8 and 5 bytes as NCRs in the best case

can imagine implementations in which it's a pain to convert UTF-8 to NCRs, e.g. if all your strings are UTF-8 encoded in a database and you just get bytes back and print them straight out, and don't have an easy way to do substitutions on characters instead of bytes
Philip`: store it as NCRs in the database ;)
Hixie: fwiw, I just noticed that the tree builder stack already has mutable data on it beyond the element nodes
Hixie: table elements have a taint bit
for dealing with foster parenting spaces and other text
is thinking of e.g. http://golem.ph.utexas.edu/~distler/code/instiki/svn/annotate/head%3A/lib/stringsupport.rb where is_utf8? indicates that all the string-processing is done on bytes
(Hmm, that code is going to think &#65536; is invalid utf8?)
Hixie: was your foster parenting change editorial?
Hixie: I'm trying to work out if there was any change other than addressing the case where a script has moved the table into a DocumentFragment
Philip`: did you have a good way of foster parenting text that doesn't cause single-char text nodes and that doesn't keep reallocating the buffer of a pre-existing text node?
in general, I don't want to fetch an existing text node back from the DOM and append to it
seems like asking for trouble in crazy script scenarios
should I try to buffer a run of foster-parented text but not coalesce it with pre-existing non-foster-parented text?

hsivonen: I think the idea was that you would only have to extend a text node if it was the last node you inserted into the document, which (hopefully) means you can delay inserting it into the document and just build up the string in memory, and then when you next insert a non-text node you go back and insert that combined text node first
OK. so I need to be able to foster-parent upon flushing :-(

hsivonen: "... if that node has a child immediately before where the character is to be inserted, and that child is a Text node, and that Text node was the last node that the parser inserted into the document, then the character must be appended to that Text node" - the "last node" bit is relevant
ok
I guess now is as good time as any to finally fix this
I've never actually tried implementing that, so I don't know if it's feasible in practice
but at some point in the past it seemed to me like it'd possibly work okay (and it would avoid the quadratic performance issues)
I don't like the idea of making flush check a flag, but I guess it's peanuts in the grand scheme of things
feels good about writing code instead of email ratholing today
You mean the flag can trigger anaphylaxis?
hsivonen:  I work on the mac an my capture software is iShowU
it lets you set up circles like that
nessy: thanks. (I use Snapz Pro X)
but I would prefer if it didn't use circles on everything, e.g. click on scrollbar

(I guess your Java implementation has the same problem that Python/JS/etc ones would, with <table>aaaaaaaaaa having O(n^2) performance if it was appending each character to the text node's immutable string?)
Philip`: right
Philip`: Gecko's strings are mutable, but IIRC, the DOM tries to not have dead weight buffers
(Non-linear performance is pretty annoying, e.g. when someone accidentally hit an exponential case in a regexp in the html5lib sanitiser)
(so I suppose html5lib should be careful to avoid these quadratic things too, because people rely on the library and don't want it to suffer from DOS attacks)
which reminds me that all my growing buffers don't have upper limits against malicious content
like <aaaaaaa... with a script serving an unbounded number of 'a's
The longest tag name I see is 594 characters

<metaname"keywords"content="agorà,provincie,regioni,comuni,istituzioni,italia,commercio,sport,dante,libertà,liberale,liberalismo,liberismo,parlamento,camera,senato,capitalismo,free,informazioni,editoria,associazioni,formazione,forum,sicurezza,cultura,europa,comunicazione,comuni,circuito,stampa,manifestazioni,iscrizioni,rete,società,pli,elezioni,partiti,politica,politiche,politici,croce,einaudi,marx,berlusconi,d'alema,rutelli,ulivo,polo,laici,occupaz
Validator.nu protects itself by limiting the length of the network stream, but I need something else for Gecko
(I guess you don't want to fatally abort when pages do silly things like that, but I'm not sure that anyone would object to truncation)
hsivonen: Isn't Gecko equally vulnerable to malicious content like <script>a='a';while(1)a+=a</script> ?
Philip`: I haven't tried
annevk: i'm sure i've acknowledged that one many times
hsivonen: and the taint bit proved to be a huge pain in the ass :-)
hsivonen: which revision?
re <meta charset>, lachy raises an interesting point
Hixie: the one that changed the paragraph starting with "The foster parent element is"
tries to look up the rev

since there can't be an xml decl, and since we're assuming the site can't set the http headers to give the encoding (otherwise we wouldn't need the meta charset), we have to assume that the document is either utf-8 or utf-16.
in which case, the meta charset isn't needed since you can just use a bom
which is already allowed
Hixie: bom vs <meta> was also discussed
Hixie: r2732
Hixie, after having thought about it more, I would allow only <meta charset="UTF-8"/> in XHTML. Anything else should be an error
BOMs are invisible metadata
Even after a second look, I can't figure out the non-editorial aspect of r2732 if there is one
i guess i could be convinced that we could allow it for utf-8 only, since in that case it doesn't do anything in xml anyway and all it does in text/html is make the default match xml
hsivonen: looking
thinks that anything that relys on BOMs is bad
oh, BOMs, those things you can never rely on tools outputting
thinks that UTF-16 *without* a BOM is bad
relying on a UTF-8 BOM is bad. Relying on UTF-16 BOM is good.
UTF-16 is general is bad...
hsivonen: It may be bad to output it without a BOM but since people generally can't see the BOM, it is hard for them to tell if they got it right
Watch out for unexploded BOMs
So BOMs rely on a "tools will save us" kind of argument
hsivonen: it's not an editorial change.
Hixie: so what's the change?
hsivonen: the foster parent element is no longer defined in terms of its parent, only in terms of the stack.
jgraham, I'm not aware of any UTF-16 capable editor that doesn't always output the BOM
and it's non-trivial to strip it
but that does make UTF-16 bad for use in server side includes
I would be more convinced by a survey of billions of web pages showing that all UTF-16 ones always have BOMs :)
hsivonen: the non-fragment case was changed from having two conditions -- if parent, if no parent -- to always doing what the original "no parent" case did
Hixie: the definition still first uses the parent of the table if there is one
it does?
how so?
is there some other text somewhere that i missed?
Hixie: or then "the parent of foo in the stack of open element" is a really unobvious way of saying you don't actually care about the actual parent
but the spec doesn't say that unless i'm misreading it
the definition of "foster parent element" only uses the term "parent" in the term "foster parent element" itself
now this is embarassing. I'm reading my diff window the wrong way round
heh
it happens :-)
The simplification doesn't really simplify things much though, since you still need to check if the foster parent is the actual parent to decide if you insertBefore or appendChild
yeah but you don't have to do that in the parser thread
hsivonen: your diff view should probably have fancy colors to avoid that mistake :)
wonders just how many UTF-16 documents there actually are
you can do that off on the main thread
Hixie, would you like the meta charset discussion summarised into an email so you don't forget about it?
Lachy: or a bug, yeah.
ok, I'll bug it
thanks
i hope it's what sam meant
Hixie: thanks
hsivonen: does that resolve that issue to your satisfaction?
if it is what sam meant, i'm still surprised that i've never actually replied to that issue
i'm sure he's raised it on the whatwg before
Hixie: either way works. the old way just would have required passing one extra pointer to the main thread
Out of the five UTF-16 pages in my collection, all have a DOM
the last few times he's mentioned it has always been on the public-html list in passing as something where he didn't get his way, i just assumed that meant that the issue had been resolved
oh well
(5 out of 130K)
hsivonen: k
Uh
s/DOM/BOM/
Hixie: s/painter/pointer/ (in the load algoritm)
Philip`: any of them have internal declarations claiming to be UTF-8? :-)
assumed Sam was referring to his namespaces-in-HTML proposal
Hixie: actually, they both require the same number of pointers to be passed
thinks that 5 might be in the realm of samll number statistics :)
One says charset="unicode"
Philip`: i've _definitely_ sent replies back on _that_ subject
Lachy: did I read it correctly that no one is proposing to honor <meta charset> in XHTML?
zcorpan: thanks
http://www.hotellikarhu.com/ says utf-8
Hixie: so I'm OK with either, but if you'd prefer reverting to the old way, I'd prefer knowing now
hsivonen: i'm fine with the text now. it's simpler.
ap, yes
Hixie: ok. thanks
hsivonen: and still doesn't throw content away.
annevk2: good, thx
hsivonen: (which your original proposal would have)
ap: don't worry, that would be a layer violation, and we won't do that
we only violate layers when legacy content forces us to
Hmm, one of the five isn't utf-16, so I've got no idea why my grep thought it was
http://www.prhoffman.com/site-map.htm says no charset at all
Hixie: validating Lachy's proposed change would violate layers, though, but the violation in the infrastructure is already needed for URL validation
http://www.archimage.net/silvia2.html asserts via HTTP that it's iso-8859-1
and via <meta> claims it's charset=unicode
http://www.rimetea-torocko.com/ claims it's charset=iso-8859-1
Oops, it's more than five, some just scrolled off my screen
hsivonen, how would it violate the layers? All you would need to check is that it's "UTF-8" (case insensitive) and that the document's encoding is UTF-8 too.
Lachy: in proper layering, the application layer doesn't know the encoding of the XML document
ok
http://www.oregongolf.com/ - aha, there's one without a BOM
http://www.southern-jet.com/ claims to be iso-8859-1
Oh, so it's actually 30 pages that look like UTF-16
which is a bit more than 5
And at least one has no BOM
Which is like 3 +/- a lot %
attempts to upload the list, before realising he's connected to the wrong Dreamhost server and so the files he uploads aren't actually accessible from the web
http://philip.html5.org/data/pages-that-look-like-utf16.txt - that's better
If anyone wants to bother looking through all those pages and working out which ones have BOMs, feel free :-)
but at least there's definitely one without
(These are the pages matching (?i)\x00[a-z]\x00[a-z]\x00, minus .jpg and .JPG and .doc and .wma files)
this seems useful http://blog.nihilogic.dk/2009/02/html5-canvas-cheat-sheet.html
ok, dealt with all the video feedback
(other than caption stuff)
Hixie: thanks :)
looks good on first read

it's interesting that the table on this page uses summary="" itself, but it contains information that would have been useful to me if I didn't have to look at the source to see it. http://www.paciellogroup.com/blog/misc/summary.html
That use of summary doesn't comply with WCAG2 AIUI
seems like that should be before or after the table labelled as "Conclusion:"
Although I don't really understand WCAG2
(specifically it doens't use the summary as indicated in http://www.w3.org/TR/WCAG20-TECHS/H73.html but I don't know if that is just supposed to be a suggestion or what)
jgraham: that's non-normative :)
zcorpan: Does WCAG have any normative conditions?
well in a shocking turn of events, i've actually run out of urgent feedback that isn't blocked on other stuff
In any case violating non-normative suggestions about how to best use the attribute in an article designed to show that the attribute is used correctly is... interesting
Hixie, take a holiday for a few weeks and relax :-)
jgraham: yes, http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#content-structure-separation-programmatic is normative
i was thinking that i could do the editorial stuff sam was saying i should do
Hixie, bug 6613 isn't blocked by anything
i haven't looked at the bugs
are any of them urgent?
I don't know. That's the one I just filed.
Hixie: my issues! address my issues first!
if you have any that affect implementations, let me know
if they're bugs, mark them P1 or critical (or both)
http://www.w3.org/Bugs/Public/show_bug.cgi?id=6336 seems fixed in the spec already
cool
http://www.w3.org/Bugs/Public/show_bug.cgi?id=6438 and http://www.w3.org/Bugs/Public/show_bug.cgi?id=6462 and http://www.w3.org/Bugs/Public/show_bug.cgi?id=6494 would probably make pf people happy
In my opinion, it doesn't make sense to stir things around bug 6494 before the group speccing ATAG decides what they want authoring tools to do
http://www.w3.org/Bugs/Public/show_bug.cgi?id=6353 seems fixed now
hsivonen: 6494 doesn't suggest any normative changes but i guess it might stir things anyway
i guess we do want to disallow cyclic references in headers="", huh
even though it doesn't cause any harm algorithm-wise
hsivonen: you ok with checking for this and flagging it?
Hixie: yeah, eventually, but it'll probably wait on other higher-priority stuff
k
holy crap, a CFL light just blew on me
i've only had it two years!
what kind of crap is this!
Hixie: time for a new blog post?
hah
i don't care as much about CFL lights as about my LED bike lights :-)
Hixie: I just witnessed one go bad in under a month
under a month! it was probably still under warranty!
presumably you can only claim warranty if you kept the receipt. But who keeps those for everything?
I might complain if I have another reason to visit the seller premises in the near future
Lachy: i do for things i might find broken and want to return
hsivonen: you really think i shouldn't do 6494 yet?
Hixie: yes
did steve just point-blank admit to trolling on public-html
or am i seeing things
Hixie: I think we should wait for concrete ATAG 2.0 draft text and then make machine-checkable conformance broad enough to make conforming all outputs of ATAG 2.0-recommended authoring tool behavior
you had me at "yes"
Hixie: either he is being sarcastic or he is admitting trolling
or he implied "... according to WCAG 2 techniques with which i disagree"
assuming we're talking about the same thing here :)
zcorpan: wouldn't that be trolling?
zcorpan, I think the trolling was where he said "I used the summary in this way on prupose, because i figured that people would look at it and comment on its incorrect use."
so who *does* agree with the WCAG advice here?
Philip`: I'll try to make SAX Tree and XOM tree builders not suck perf-wise when there's a lot of stuff to foster parent
we'll see if I break something...
hsivonen: uh yeah i guess it would

considering the actual conformance criteria in WCAG2 are so vague and incomprehensible without reading the Understanding and Techniques documents, choosing to ignore the advisory techniques you disagree with seems to leaves them open to a lot of interpretation
s/seems to leaves/leaves/
Lachy: yeah, I think that's a pretty significant flaw. particularly in a document that clearly has been written as basis for litigation

"There may also be cases where it may be a judgment call about what information should appear in text and what would need to be directly associated, and it may be most appropriate to duplicate some information (for instance, in an HTML table, providing the summary both in the paragraph before the table and in the summary attribute of the table itself). However, wherever possible it is necessary for the information to be programmatically determined rath
er than providing a text description before encountering the table."
-- http://www.w3.org/TR/UNDERSTANDING-WCAG20/content-structure-separation-programmatic.html
So WCAG2 recommends dupicating information just to achieve programmatic association?!
I love the use of "wherever possible" in the light of comments on the use of "when possible" in HTML Design Principles
LOL
well, this is an informative document. WCAG 1 had "when possible" in normative criteria
doesn't think it makes sense to have normative criteria for "guidelines" in the first place
or the title should have been WCAR
it seems to me WCAG family of documents wants to have its cake and eat it too when it comes to normativity
hmm autobuffer="" seems nice, i had only thought about using heuristics
wonders if http://www.whatwg.org/issues/top has turned out to be of significant value or not
not enough people voted on issues for it to be valuable
wonders if it's bad for SAX Tree to have a tree node per character for foster-parented text
wonders what a tree node is
wonders what a character is
if I fix the O(n^2) search behavior
Philip`: UTF-16 code unit
zcorpan: a node is an object with 7 pointers and two ints

(aaaaaa is presumably easier to handle than
aaaaaa because in the former case you could just pass a string of consecutive characters into the tree builder and treat them as a single unit)
seems like no big deal in usual cases and bad in the kind of cases Philip` finds on the Web
The case where I had problems was because a bug in my code put a megabyte of null bytes after a <table> - I don't think I encountered any real web content with the same problem
ok. then I don't optimize further than eliminating the O(n^2) behavior
It seems a bit bad that I could cause you to use ~576 bytes of memory for every byte I send over the network
Hixie, how about also adding a note to clarify that <meta charset> doesn't actually have any effect in XHTML even if set to another value
Philip`: yeah. the alternative is adding the complexity of early coalescing...

Hixie: "There must not be more than one element with a charset attribute per document." sounds a bit misinterpretable, because you can have <script charset/><script charset/> in a document, so maybe it should be clarified to say "meta element"
which would have the benefit of saving per code-unit method invocation overhead with all tree builders
foster parenting is such an annoyance
basically, something to preempt the bad advice about needing to use it to specify the encoding of XHTML, which we've already seen plenty of for XHTML1
is now thoroughly confused about when it is OK to disagree with various parts of WCAG
Does it make a difference if one is a self-proclaimed accessbility expert or not?
hsivonen: Would early coalescing still result in aaa... using ~576 bytes of memory for every 5 bytes I send over the network?
(where '5 bytes' means 'approximately 1 bit, if I use compression')
fixed the charset rules
thanks for the feedback
Philip`: what's your pointer size if you get 576 instead of 120 or 92?
Philip`: but yes
Philip`: note that you can already make SAX Tree use a lot of memory by sending bab...

"the resource must be encoded using the UTF-8 character encoding" - what does that mean? Could I write a file containing <meta charset="utf-8"/> and encode the characters as UTF-8, and then serve it as application/xhtml+xml;charset=iso-8859-1? I still encoded the resource as UTF-8
hsivonen: Um...
hsivonen: 64 bytes
Philip`: my pointer size is 64 *bits* ;-)
hsivonen: I realise that now :-)
Philip`: that would be a violation of some other rule
hsivonen: so it'd be like 7*64 + 2*32 bits, which is like 64 bytes, plus a little bit of overhead for the JVM, I guess
hsivonen: When we have 512bit cpus then Philip` will look prophetic
Hixie: Even if the document is perfectly valid iso-8859-1?
Philip`: if it's actually US-ASCII, and thus both UTF-8 and ISO-8859-1, I don't really care if there's a mismatch.
Philip`: on of the requirements for SAX Tree is being able to reconstuct SAX Locator data upon playback
oops it's 7 pointers and 4 ints
Hixie: What if it's not US-ASCII, but still is both UTF-8 and ISO-8859-1?
plus JVM overhead, which I assume to be at least two pointers and one int (considering that there's an array involved)
(with different meaning in each)
can't count anymore
Philip`: well then there is a bug, because assuming you only have one document, one of the encodings is wrong.
anyway, a handful of pointers and ints :-)
wonders if rubys wanted status updates only on the "Open issues with open and pending review action items" or on everything on the agenda
the latter being way the hell too many things to comment on
hsivonen: Fair enough :-)
considering how stable the parsing algorithm is, it changes surprisingly often.
Hixie: why no legacy encoding declaration for xhtml?
hm?
hsivonen: yeah :-(
hsivonen: it'll be interesting to see how much the spec changes once we're in CR
hsivonen: (If you're fixing non-linear behaviour, will you add some limit on xxx too?)
Philip`: not today, no
Hixie: you only allowed <meta charset="utf-8"/> in xhtml, not <meta http-equiv="content-type" content="text/html; charset=utf-8"/>
Philip`: I'm only fixing insertBefore in SAX Tree and XOM not to search the children of the foster parent repeatedly
hsivonen: Okay
zcorpan: Encouraging people to say their application/xhtml+xml files are text/html seems like a confusing idea
and given how many restrictions there already are when writing polyglot documents, having to use <meta charset> doesn't seem like a big deal
zcorpan: yes? we only need one way to do this, as far as i can tell.
Hixie: ok, fair enough. it wasn't clear to me if it was intentional or not
yeah
Hixie: is it intended that the requirements in #character-encoding-declaration apply to xml too?
no
though i suppose it should
goes to change that
again
http://getluky.net/2009/01/08/a-warning-about-the-real-cost-of-microformats/ seems to apply equally well to rdfa

When I sort of tried using hCard once, the main difficulty was that its required structure didn't match the markup structure I wanted to use, so I ended up adding stuff like , to get the right output for both hCard and visual display
and if I was doing something more complex, like having details for multiple people mixed together in the same page, it seems it'd probably be impossible to get right

RDFa seems much better in that regard, because you're just specifying a load of triples and you can put them wherever you want, rather than having to nest your markup precisely how someone thought your data should be nested
Philip`, that's the same problem I encountered when I used hCard once

The spec should, for parsing, define what the output tree should be like. What is doing the parsing should be irrelevant.
jgraham: I can't remember :P
gsnedders: Libraries don't necessarily output trees; it only makes sense to require a tree in (scripted) browsers, where there has to be a DOM tree that results from parsing
Philip`: What else could the library do? It needs to be a tree — it doesn't work streaming without fatal errors.
If you don't have a whole browser, HTML5 doesn't define any way to determine the output of parsing, so there's no restriction on libraries
gsnedders: You could stream a mutation event
You could construct an internal tree and then stream it out as a series of events
You could output a stream of RDF triples
